case_name: Kalianna Gounder v. Palani Gounder and T.P. Sengottaiah

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1360 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1360 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated January 19, 1962 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 351 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 19, 1962 of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 351 of 1958.

facts.text: Palani Gounder and his son T.P. Sengottaiah own Survey No. 765-B in Kugallur village.

anchor.surface_text: Palani Gounder and his son T.P. Sengottaiah--hereinafter collectively called the defendants--own Survey No. 765-B in Kugallur village.

facts.text: Kalianna Gounder agreed on July 4, 1956 to purchase the land from defendants for Rs. 12,000.

anchor.surface_text: Kalianna Gounder--hereinafter called the plaintiff--agreed on July 4, 1956 to purchase from the defendants that land for Rs. 12,000.

facts.text: Memorandum executed reciting Rs. 2,000 paid as advance by plaintiff to defendants.

anchor.surface_text: A memorandum reciting that Rs. 2,000 were paid as advance by the plaintiff to the defendants was executed by the plaintiff and the defendants.

facts.text: Memorandum written by Ramamurthy Iyer and signatures attested by Kaliyanna Gounder.

anchor.surface_text: The memorandum was written by one Ramamurthy Iyer and the signatures thereon were attested by one Kaliyanna Gounder.

facts.text: On July 7, 1956, defendants informed plaintiff by letter that only Rs. 350 paid, not Rs. 2,000, balance Rs. 1,650 not paid within three days, agreement cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: On July 7, 1956, the defendants informed the plaintiff by a letter that, only a sum of Rs. 350 was paid by the plaintiff to the defendants and number Rs. 2,000 as recited in the memorandum, and since the balance of Rs. 1,650 which was promised to be paid within three days was number paid, the agreed stood cancelled.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit for specific performance and deposited Rs. 10,000 in court.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff on receipt of the letter instituted an action in the Civil Court for a decree for specific performance of the agreement, and deposited in Court Rs. 10,000 which according to him was the balance of the purchase price due by him.

facts.text: Defendants in written statement contended only Rs. 350 paid on July 4, 1956, balance Rs. 1,650 promised within three days, not paid, agreement cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants filed their written statement contending, inter alia, that they were in urgent need of money, and they had agreed to sell the land to the plaintiff, but the plaintiff paid only Rs. 350 on July 4, 1956, and obtained possession of the memorandum on a representation that he will pay the balance of Rs. 1,650 within three days and since the amount was number paid the agreement was cancelled,

facts.text: Defendants contended agreement altered by adding words 'Clear the debts and execute the sale deed free from encumbrance'.

anchor.surface_text: and that in any event the agreement having been altered in material particulars, after it was executed, by adding the words Clear the debt. s and execute the sale deed free from encumbrance, the suit was number maintainable.

facts.text: Trial Court upheld plaintiff's claim and decreed specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of First Instance upheld the plaintiffs claim and decreed the suit for specific performance of the agreement.

facts.text: Madras High Court reversed trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the High Court of Madras the decree was reversed.

facts.text: High Court held plaintiff paid only Rs. 350 on July 4, 1956, obtained agreement on representation to pay Rs. 1,650, not paid, suit not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, held that the plaintiff paid Rs. 350 only on July 4 1956, and on a representation that he will pay the balance of Rs. 1,650 payable as advance obtained possession of the agreement of sale, and the plaintiff number having paid the amount payable by him the suit for specific performance of the agreement was maintainable.

facts.text: High Court held agreement altered in material particulars by adding covenant relating to clearance of encumbrance after execution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the agreement was altered in material particulars by adding the covenant relating to clearance of encumbrance after the memorandam was executed

facts.text: Plaintiff asserted paid full Rs. 2,000 on July 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff in his statement before the Court asserted that he paid the full amount of Rs. 2,000 on July 4, 1956 to the defendants.

facts.text: Ramamurthy Iyer supported plaintiff, as writer of document.

anchor.surface_text: He-was supported by his witness Ramamurthy Iyef--the writer of the document.

facts.text: T.P. Sengottaiah asserted only Rs. 350 paid at execution, balance demanded, promised within three days, not paid, agreement cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: On the side of the defendants there is the evidence of T.P. Sengottaiah who asserted that only Rs. 350 were paid at the time of the execution of the memorandum and when the balance was demanded the plaintiff promised to pay the same within three days. He also stated that the amount was number paid within three days as promised and on that account the agreement was cancelled.

facts.text: T.P. Sengottaiah's testimony supported by attesting witness.

anchor.surface_text: His testimony was supported by the attesting witness.

facts.text: Trial Judge accepted plaintiff's and Ramamurthy Iyer's testimony.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Trial Judge accepted the testimony of the plaintiff and his witness Ramamurthy Iyer.

facts.text: High Court preferred testimony of T.P. Sengottaiah and attesting witness.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the testimony of T.P. Sengottiah and the attesting witness should be preferred.

facts.text: Memorandum recites defendants received Rs. 2,000 as advance, plaintiff to pay balance within 60 days.

anchor.surface_text: The memorandum expressly recites that the defendants have received Rs. 2,000 as advance and within sixty days from today the plaintiff should pay the balance of the sale price and execute the sale deed. Failing that, besides losing the advance amount, numberhing is binding as per the agreement.

facts.text: Plaintiff is illiterate agriculturist, defendants educated, second defendant President of Local Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff is an illiterate agriculturist, whereas the defendants are educated people, and the second defendant was at the material time President of the Local Panchayat.

facts.text: Plaintiff deposited Rs. 10,000 in court on July 14, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On July 14, 1956, exactly ten days after t, he date on which the agreement was entered into, the plaintiff deposited in Court a sum of Rs. 10,000 in the action for specific performance commenced by him.

facts.text: Plaintiff received defendants' letter on July 14, 1956 and instituted suit same day.

anchor.surface_text: But it was the plaintiffs case that he received the numberice on July 14, 1956, and on the same day he instituted the suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court held defendants' story of only Rs. 350 paid untrue.

anchor.surface_text: Having carefully considered the evidence we are of the view that the story of the defendants that only Rs. 350 were paid to them on July 4, 1956, and number Rs. 2,000 as recited in the memorandum is untrue and has been put up as an excuse for resiling from the agreement.

facts.text: Words 'Clear the debts and execute the sale deed free from encumbrance' written in cramped style before schedule.

anchor.surface_text: but from the cross- examination of the writer and the plaintiffs witnesses and also from the testimony of T.P. Sengottiah and his witnesses it does number appear that the words Clear the debts and execute the sale deed free from encumbrance were written in a cramped style. This sentence occurs immediately before the Schedule of property sold and after the first three paragraphs of the companyvenants of the memorandum.

facts.text: No discussion at time of execution about encumbrances on land, no evidence of encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant and his witnesses have admitted that there was number discussion at the time of the writing and execution of the agreement about the encumbrances upon the land. There is number even evidence that there were any encumbrances subsisting on the land.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court decree, restored trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and the decree of the Trial Court is restored with companyts in this Court and in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The second plea that there was an alteration in the memorandum in material particulars cannot also be sustained. The original document is number before us, but from the cross- examination of the writer and the plaintiffs witnesses and also from the testimony of T.P. Sengottiah and his witnesses it does number appear that the words Clear the debts and execute the sale deed free from encumbrance were written in a cramped style. This sentence occurs immediately before the Schedule of property sold and after the first three paragraphs of the companyvenants of the memorandum. There was numberreason for the writer to leave any space which companyld be availed of to add this sentence after the document was executed. There is numberdenial that the sentence has been written by Ramamurthy. It is true that the High Court has observed that the ink in which the sentence was written appeared to be slightly different in shade from the rest of the document. But Ramamurthy Iyer has deposed that it was number true that the portion in the, agreement relating to the encumbrance was written subsequent to the agreement in companylusion with the plaintiff. He explained that the ink in his fountain-pen was exhausted when he wrote with one pen, and he wrote the portion after reading the document with another fountain-pen, and since the portion was written in a hurry the ink may have differed. According to him he did number numberice any difference in ink. There is numberreason to disbelieve the testimony of Ramamurthy Iyer. Even if it be assumed that the sentence regarding encumbrance was written after the deed was executed it will number invalidate the deed. The second defendant and his witnesses have admitted that there was number discussion at the time of the writing and execution of the agreement about the encumbrances upon the land. There is number even evidence that there were any encumbrances subsisting on the land. Ordinarily when property is agreed to be sold for a price, it would be the duty of the vendor to clear it of all the encumbrances before executing the sale deed. The alteration, if any, cannot therefore be regarded as material. As observed in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 11, 3rd Edn., Art. 599 at A material alteration is one which varies the rights, liabilities, or legal position of the parties as ascertained by the deed in its original state, or otherwise varies the legal effect of the instrument as originally expressed,or reduces to certainty some provision which was origInally unascertained and as such void, or may otherwise prejudice the party bound by the deed as originally executed. The effect of making such an alteration, without the companysent of the party bound, is exactly the same as that of canceling the deed. It is also stated in Art. 604 at pp. 370 and An alteration made in a deed, after its execution, in some particular which is number material does number in any way affect the validity of the deed an alteration is number material which does number vary the legal effect of the deed in its original state, but merely expresses that which was implied by law in the deed as originally written, or which carries out the intention of the parties already apparent on the face of the deed, provided that the alteration does number otherwise prejudice the party liable thereunder.

concepts.interpretation: Supreme Court holds alteration, if any, not material as it merely expresses implied duty of vendor to clear encumbrances; quotes Halsbury's definition and Privy Council approval; alteration without consent cancels deed only if material

arguments.claim: Defendants' case of relying on bare promise without endorsement on memorandum unreliable

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff is an illiterate agriculturist, whereas the defendants are educated people, and the second defendant was at the material time President of the Local Panchayat. The case of the defendants that they relied upon the bare word of the plaintiff that he will pay the balance of Rs. 1,650 within three days and on that representation they parted with the memorandum is, in our judgment, unreliable.

arguments.claim: No reason to disbelieve Ramamurthy Iyer's testimony

anchor.surface_text: The High Court discarded the testimony of Ramamurthy Iyer on the view that he was inimical to the defendants. We have been taken through his evidence and we see numberjustification for hold- ing that his testimony companyld number be believed. If Ramamurthy Iyer was an enemy of the defendants, it is very unlikely that they would permit him to write out an important document at their residence.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court has observed that the ink in which the sentence was written appeared to be slightly different in shade from the rest of the document. But Ramamurthy Iyer has deposed that it was number true that the portion in the, agreement relating to the encumbrance was written subsequent to the agreement in companylusion with the plaintiff. He explained that the ink in his fountain-pen was exhausted when he wrote with one pen, and he wrote the portion after reading the document with another fountain-pen, and since the portion was written in a hurry the ink may have differed.

arguments.claim: Even if sentence added after execution, not material as no discussion of encumbrances, none existed, implied duty of vendor to clear encumbrances

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant and his witnesses have admitted that there was number discussion at the time of the writing and execution of the agreement about the encumbrances upon the land. There is number even evidence that there were any encumbrances subsisting on the land. Ordinarily when property is agreed to be sold for a price, it would be the duty of the vendor to clear it of all the encumbrances before executing the sale deed.

arguments.claim: Material alteration defined as one varying rights/liabilities/legal position; non-material alteration does not invalidate deed (Halsbury's Laws of England)

anchor.surface_text: As observed in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 11, 3rd Edn., Art. 599 at A material alteration is one which varies the rights, liabilities, or legal position of the parties as ascertained by the deed in its original state, or otherwise varies the legal effect of the instrument as originally expressed,or reduces to certainty some provision which was origInally unascertained and as such void, or may otherwise prejudice the party bound by the deed as originally executed.

arguments.claim: Alteration not material if expresses what implied by law or carries out apparent intention without prejudice (Halsbury); applied in Nathu Lal v. Gomti Kuar (Privy Council)

anchor.surface_text: It is also stated in Art. 604 at pp. 370 and An alteration made in a deed, after its execution, in some particular which is number material does number in any way affect the validity of the deed an alteration is number material which does number vary the legal effect of the deed in its original state, but merely expresses that which was implied by law in the deed as originally written, or which carries out the intention of the parties already apparent on the face of the deed, provided that the alteration does number otherwise prejudice the party liable thereunder. This rule has been applied by the Privy Council in Nathu Lal and Ors. v. Mussamat Gomti Kuar and Others 1 .

arguments.claim: Covenant does not vary rights/liabilities as defendants liable to clear encumbrances anyway

anchor.surface_text: Since the defendants were liable to clear the encumbrances, if any, subsisting on the land before executing the sale deed, assuming that the companyenant was incorporated after the execution of the deed, it cannot be regarded as a material alteration on that account, for it does number alter the rights or liabilities of the parties or the legal effect of the instrument.

holdings.text: the story of the defendants that only Rs. 350 were paid to them on July 4, 1956, and not Rs. 2,000 as recited in the memorandum is untrue and has been put up as an excuse for resiling from the agreement

anchor.surface_text: Having carefully considered the evidence we are of the view that the story of the defendants that only Rs. 350 were paid to them on July 4, 1956, and number Rs. 2,000 as recited in the memorandum is untrue and has been put up as an excuse for resiling from the agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conflicting testimony resolved on broad probabilities; express recital prima facie proof of payment; heavy burden on defendants to disprove not discharged; plaintiff's deposit of Rs.10,000 shortly after shows funds availability; educated defendants unlikely to release document on bare promise without endorsement; Ramamurthy Iyer's testimony credible.

holdings.text: The second plea that there was an alteration in the memorandum in material particulars cannot also be sustained

anchor.surface_text: The second plea that there was an alteration in the memorandum in material particulars cannot also be sustained. The original document is not before us, but from the cross- examination of the writer and the plaintiffs witnesses and also from the testimony of T.P.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of cramped handwriting or post-execution insertion; natural position in document; ink difference explained credibly by writer; no reason to disbelieve Ramamurthy Iyer.

holdings.text: Even if it be assumed that the sentence regarding encumbrance was written after the deed was executed it will not invalidate the deed

anchor.surface_text: There is no reason to disbelieve the testimony of Ramamurthy Iyer. Even if it be assumed that the sentence regarding encumbrance was written after the deed was executed it will not invalidate the deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alteration not material; no discussion of encumbrances at execution and none existed; merely expresses ordinary implied duty of vendor to clear encumbrances before sale deed.

holdings.text: Ordinarily when property is agreed to be sold for a price, it would be the duty of the vendor to clear it of all the encumbrances before executing the sale deed

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant and his witnesses have admitted that there was no discussion at the time of the writing and execution of the agreement about the encumbrances upon the land. There is no even evidence that there were any encumbrances subsisting on the land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Implied legal obligation of vendor in sale agreements; alteration stating this does not vary rights or prejudice parties.

holdings.text: A material alteration is one which varies the rights, liabilities, or legal position of the parties as ascertained by the deed in its original state, or otherwise varies the legal effect of the instrument as originally expressed, or reduces to certainty some provision which was originally unascertained and as such void, or may otherwise prejudice the party bound by the deed as originally executed

anchor.surface_text: As observed in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 11, 3rd Edn., Art. 599 at A material alteration is one which varies the rights, liabilities, or legal position of the parties as ascertained by the deed in its original state, or otherwise varies the legal effect of the instrument as originally expressed,or reduces to certainty some provision which was origInally unascertained and as such void, or may otherwise prejudice the party bound by the deed as originally executed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Halsbury's definition; applied by Privy Council in Nathu Lal v. Gomti Kuar; alteration here does not vary rights/liabilities as vendor already bound to clear encumbrances.

holdings.text: when there was an express recital in the agreement that a sum of Rs. 2,000 was paid by the plaintiff and it was received by the defendants, it was not necessary for the plaintiff to lead evidence as to the source from which he obtained the money

anchor.surface_text: But when there was an express recital in the agreement that a sum of Rs. 2,000 was paid by the plaintiff and it was received by the defendants, it was not necessary for the plaintiff to lead evidence as to the source from which he obtained the money.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recital in executed document prima facie evidence of payment; shifts burden to challenger.

holdings.text: the burden of proving in the circumstances of the case, that Rs. 2,000 were not paid lay heavily upon the defendants

anchor.surface_text: But the burden of proving in the circumstances of the case, that Rs. 2,000 were number paid lay heavily upon the defendants. Again, there is strong evidence to indicate that the plaintiff had at his disposal a substantial amount on which he could have drawn.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to recital and circumstances, heavy evidentiary burden on party denying payment recited in signed agreement.

precedents.citation: Nathu Lal and Ors. v. Mussamat Gomti Kuar and Others

anchor.surface_text: Nathu Lal and Ors. v. Mussamat Gomti Kuar and Others 1 . The Judicial Committee observed in that case at p. 331 A deed is numberhing more than an instrument or agreement under seal and the principle of those cases is that any alteration in a material part of any instrument or agreement avoids it, because it thereby ceases to be the same instrument. The Judicial Committee observed at p. 333 A material alteration has been defined in the rule as one which varies the rights, liabilities or legal position of the parties ascertained by the deed, etc., and after applying that test they held that the alteration in that case was number material in the sense of altering the rights, liabilities or legal position of the parties or the legal effect of the document. L.R. 67 I.A.318.

precedents.case_name: Nathu Lal and Ors. v. Mussamat Gomti Kuar and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: A material alteration in a deed is one which varies the rights, liabilities or legal position of the parties or the legal effect of the instrument; alterations that merely express what was implied by law or carry out the intention of the parties without prejudice do not affect validity.
precedents.cited_holding: the alteration in that case was not material in the sense of altering the rights, liabilities or legal position of the parties or the legal effect of the document

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and the decree of the Trial Court is restored with costs in this Court

anchor.surface_text: Having carefully considered the evidence we are of the view that the story of the defendants that only Rs. 350 were paid to them on July 4, 1956, and number Rs. 2,000 as recited in the memorandum is untrue and has been put up as an excuse for resiling from the agreement.
The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and the decree of the Trial Court is restored with costs in this Court

anchor.surface_text: The second plea that there was an alteration in the memorandum in material particulars cannot also be sustained. The original document is not before us, but from the cross- examination of the writer and the plaintiffs witnesses and also from the testimony of T.P.
The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and the decree of the Trial Court is restored with costs in this Court

edges.explanation: Definition of material alteration addresses the central issue of whether alteration was material

anchor.surface_text: As observed in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 11, 3rd Edn., Art. 599 at A material alteration is one which varies the rights, liabilities, or legal position of the parties as ascertained by the deed in its original state, or otherwise varies the legal effect of the instrument as originally expressed,or reduces to certainty some provision which was origInally unascertained and as such void, or may otherwise prejudice the party bound by the deed as originally executed.
The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and the decree of the Trial Court is restored with costs in this Court
